The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow taxpayers to request mediation or arbitration in any case unless the Secretary has specifically excluded the issue or class of cases. Independent mediators will be involved in the process. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows taxpayers to elect mediation by an independent individual not employed by the IRS Office of Appeals. Taxpayers sharing costs equally with the IRS and selecting mediators from a recognized roster. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows taxpayers to elect mediation by an independent individual not employed by the IRS Office of Appeals. Taxpayers can choose mediators from a recognized roster, with exceptions for individuals or small businesses meeting specific income criteria. The amendment allows taxpayers to elect mediation or arbitration at the time of filing with the Office of Appeals or before appeal deliberations start. Effective upon enactment of the Act. SEC. 9. Extension of time for contesting IRS levy to 3 years. Amendments apply to levies made after enactment and those made before if the 9-month period has not expired. SEC. 10. Waiver of installment agreement fee for taxpayers with adjusted gross income below 250 percent of the poverty level who agree to electronic payments. Effective upon enactment. SEC. 11. The amendments made by this section apply to petitions filed after the date of enactment of this Act. SEC. 13 increases monetary penalties for unauthorized disclosures of information in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 from $5,000 to $10,000.
